text: I don’t follow immediately. The unease in my chest feels like a nail—if I don’t pull it out, I won’t sleep tonight.
“You two go up first. I’ll… check if there’s another exit.”
Lucia freezes, then shakes her head at once. “No! It’s too dangerous—”
Alicia turns her face slightly, her tone crisp and cold. “One minute.”
She doesn’t look back, but she allows it—as if she’s long been used to someone taking one last look here.
I crouch down, pretending to fix my shoelaces, my eyes sweeping over the remnants of the formation.
The blue glow on the ground should have faded by now, yet a few thin lines are still slowly retracting—like a wound stitching itself shut.
In the corner of the wall is a circular scrape mark, identical to the ring-shaped token in her palm.
I reach out and touch the scratch. A strange warmth pulses against my fingertip—like metal just branded by a hot iron.
Stranger still: along the edge of the formation is a faint carving, as if someone repeatedly etched the same number with a knife tip.
I lean closer, using the dim glow to make it out—it reads “37.”
“…They didn’t carve this.”
Lucia holds her breath. “What did you see?”
Alicia finally turns around. Her gaze falls on the carved number and lingers for half a second.
“Don’t touch it.”
Her voice is quiet—but more warning than any command.
“You’ve been here many times, haven’t you?”
She doesn’t answer. She simply looks away. “Time’s up. Let’s go.”
We leave the basement. The snow and fog rush toward us, almost like a sigh of relief.
Lucia asks softly, “Did you just see… a number?”
“Yeah.”
Alicia cuts in, “Don’t discuss it on the road.”
The inn’s lights glow through the mist. Once the door shuts, the outside world feels sealed away.
